headline: It is a conventional telecommunication company
pros:
・Stability of the business, COVID did not affect the business
・Good work-life-balance, 15~20 overtime on average for me
・Generous bonus, 5 months + base salary, depending on the company's performance
cons:
・Slow pay raise, if you are a fresh graduate, you get 600USD/year raise.
・Too few international interactions, your language ability is worthless in the accounting department.
・Too many in-company systems, we use five or more systems for day-to-day operation, and three more for HR-related things.
・Recent price-cut pressure from the Government makes worsens the financial.
・Conservative, not willing to step in outside of the border, trying to protect their pie.

headline: Japanese companies try to be international but still struggled.
pros:
Overall Softbank is not a bad company at least from the view of the department I belong to. 
SoftBank is a company that encourages employees' independence, So even a new (recent) graduate your voice is also be respected. 
Since SoftBank itself use to be a start-up 10 years ago, most of the manager layers are approachable. I think this is precious for a company that has more than 10,000 employees.
cons: Like all the big companies, SoftBank also suffers from the "big business disease". Although the top manager tried very hard to avoid that, the long and slow decision-making process is everywhere. In my perspective, this is fatal for developing new business.

headline: You're lucky if you get to work here!
pros:
- Flexible work schedule schedule and easy going, fun culture.
- Great work life balance. Actually the best I've seen at any company. 
- Leadership team works hard to consistently improve and always open to feedback.
- Company promotes from within so definitely many growth opportunities. 
- Many exciting products being worked on so this is a very exciting time in the company. 
- Holiday celebrations, off-sites, occasional catered lunches, and more...
- Great office location and beautiful office with snacks, water, coffee, etc.. in the kitchen.
cons: Company constantly evolving and things can change overnight sometimes, so you have to learn to adapt quickly.

One gang member within the team who is favored makes the decision, and will become enemies with you if you have an opinion. The tech team by any means have the educational experience or the technical background to make decisions. Pepper the robot is a joke, and I don't see it making it through the robot industry.

headline: Good building, but technologically so-so
pros:
The building is really nice with great coffee and restaurant.
Good location with Shimbashi station and JR line.
Flexible time.
cons:
Highly political place, with traditional Japanese back-balling if you don't go to the Izakaya with your colleagues for example.
Very long hours, overwork. I have seen people working all night after a full-day work.
Engineers level is in general very bad.
Traditional Japanese service, not technology, driven system which lead to HR and sales having higher consideration than engineers.
Very low pay even for highly skilled people.
During my time at SoftBank nobody could explain me what was the company vision, nor what was our goals.
It's also possible to get hired as internal without relevant skills or university degree.
Very strange, politically oriented decisions from top management which leads to technical instability and distrust.

this company have a lot of debt and try to do challenging too much.

headline: There is potential but many teething issues
pros:
- SoftBank Robotics is a truly international company located in cool places, and it is very likely that your daily interactions would be with other employees in Paris or Japan or, if you are in the US, Boston or San Francisco, if not all four. Because of relatively flexible travel policies to aid cohesion in this growing organization, travel is often possible between these places as long as a good business reason can be justified.
- In all four locations (except the HQ in Shiodome, Tokyo) the culture is casual and the environment is collegial. This is particularly true of Paris and Boston.
- Boston has a small, young team and people generally joke around and play ping pong at work. San Francisco (and some times, Boston) has drinks on Friday. Paris employees often go out together and organize cool team building events outside of work.
- The people! In every office, people have been consistently smart if not brilliant, funny and kind when you meet them. Hence I recommend that it's important to go fly to the other offices when you commence your role, to visit the remote offices and meet people face to face. You are much more likely to figure out communication strategies that work across time zones and emails/calls, then trying to initiate things remotely.
- The startup turning into big company culture is still in it's teething phases, and while that results in a number of cons - the big takeaway is that you can influence things far more than you could in an established company. Always question things around you if they don't make sense (a lot probably won't but that's OK :) ), and the smart people aforementioned will most likely see your point, hear your proposal (propose how they could be different!), and you'll be in action!
- Of course, how can I forget that Pepper and Nao are so cool! This is a nascent industry, so you will have moments of pride when you see Pepper or Nao's face randomly pop up in media or journals about robotics and AI, and go to cool events such as the RoboCup or TechCrunch.
cons:
- Technical growth opportunities are currently very limited in the US since the development happens in Paris, so to really grow you would need to relocate. 
- Salaries in the US are based on Europe standards, so employees are paid well below market average. This may change soon.
- A loose structure means that sometimes double work (or no work) tends to happen, in fact even 2 people may be hired in different continents for the same responsibility. People end up doing work they are not supposed to and others end up routinely left out of the loop for information they are supposed to receive to start doing their work. But this is to be expected, and needs a lot of communication and meeting people face-to-face to fix - not just managerial level but also the working level.
- Miscommunication flows to miscommunication between management and HR. They have an unprofessional policy requiring technical employees to be escorted out even when they give notice, which is arbitrarily applied. 2 employees leaving the same function for the same other company were treated differently where 1 was escorted and the other kept their notice.

- Communicating across time zones is a challenge. The impact is felt more in offices that are not 'upstream' in the process. For example, information on new software releases or new potential customers would be released at the end rather than being communicated earlier on. People do try to solve that by sending Powerpoint reports - but this means reading a lot of Powerpoints and making sure you ask to be included in the email chain, risking potentially being overloaded with unnecessary information.

headline: Growing company

headline: Ambitious CEO, Very domestic
pros: CEO is very ambitions and willing take risks and make bold decisions. Depending on your department but it is fairly easy to get paid days off compared to traditional Japanese companies.
cons: The company claims itself to be "global" but in reality it is very domestic. Company culture is quite top-down and unless you are in management position your opinions won't matter. Management often makes decisions with out analyzing the situation well and sets goals very high which is just simply impossible to achieve. Because it grew so fast, the company wants you to work as if you are in a startup but there are so many constraints now that it grew to a company with 20,000+ employees.

headline: Great organization in a period of transition

cons:

- Last two years (2014-2015) characterized by cavalier deal-making that will take time to sort out

headline: Strange company culture

cons:
Too strong CEO & COO directions. It seems almost management teams don't have will. They only do CEO & COO directions. Mid & low level managers are same like that. Sometimes anybody don't understand why do these task. But anybody do these task. Because it seems like directions.
Many employees are lack of morals and wil.

headline: significant learning and networking experience

cons: Very fast paced work environment. All companies fall under umbrella of the larger corporation, which can slow down some administrative processes

headline: Excellent company to work for
pros: SoftBank Capital has amazing employee benefits, great people to work with, independent environment, drama free, gorgeous office environment and long paid vacations.
cons: Over the years I have worked here I haven't found there to be any cons.

headline: Typical Japanese company
pros: A company with so many industries and keep setting up new business in other areas, which means you can have quite a few job rotation chances to other newly setup areas or teams.
cons:
- A typical Japanese company.
- Many meetings in the day time.
- Business and service oriented, which means planner and sales have high position in the company, compared to technical positions.
- Not a real high tech company.

headline: Administration Office
pros: Flexible time. Easy job once you get to use to it.
cons: No stability, no willingness to localize the company, unorganized structure. A lot of unfairness between local hired employees and expats.

headline: Softbank

cons: Japanese culture really conservative

headline: Project Manager
pros: Lots of big challenges if you want.
cons: You have to work really hard and long hours, it's hard to have a balanced life......

headline: Poorly Compensated Headless Chickens
pros: If you have a strong interest in the cellphone industry, then this could be a good place to learn before leaving for greener pastures. However, the industry as a whole is well on its way to becoming a commodity business with very little room for profit, putting great downward pressure on wages.
cons: Absolutely no brand awareness, poor organization, frequent reshuffling, few skilled managers, very low compensation, lots of uncompensated overtime, lots of overtime linked to low basic compensation, very low communications skills among all employees from top to bottom,

headline: Global Business
pros: Nice people to work with. Good location (if you are in the Tokyo Office)
cons:
Oftentimes, they will hire you for a Tokyo office location and then switch your location to elsewhere within 3 months. (Happened to a many of my co-workers). In addition, the company ranks everything and publicly displays theses scores. (Your Sales results, training Tests etc. It's a clear disadvantage for foreigners)

The company claims it is "global" but is very far away from it. Many English speakers are not places in a position where they will use their English and foreigners do NOT have any hope of moving up. 

There is ALOT of overtime. Although they technically pay for overtime, may departments ask you to do "service overtime" where it means you work for free. Because of the Japanese Culture if you refuse to do service overtime you will be extremely rude and therefore shunned.

headline: CEO has strong power
pros: CEO has strong power comparing to other Japanese companies. It worked well in some case, but we have to get permission from him to move issues forward.
cons: Always there are many changes even decided issue.
